p.s: Starr's state of mind is shown by the usage of point of view and various narrative techniques, such as flashbacks.
Starr was through the entire book unsure to speak up for Khalil, because her fear of possible consequences, like King coming for her or what others think about her.
But at the end of the book she gets her mind clear and knows what she really wants to do.
She has a strong will in her mind and is desperate to speak her thoughts out, not afraid of her old conflict of identities and what others think.

To show that this change of the state of her mind happens, because of her anger and injustice for Khalil, the author uses a flashback, in wichwhich Starr sees Khalil getting shot again (He looks at me for the last time and - ll. 6-7).
This flashback makes the reader understand, that this change in her intentions did not came from nowhere.

Another example for this is her interior monologmonologue, where she says to herself in her thoughts, that she is happy while speaking out and letting her anger out (speaker happy is more my thing ll. 57-58).
This has the effect on the reader that she has a clear mind and is true with herself, with speaking up for Khalil.
The point of view used in this excerpt, is the first person protagonist narrator.
The reader only has a limited vision and knows only what Starr knows.
The reader sees through Starr's eyes and kowsknows her feelings and thoughts.
Using this point of view, makes the reader sympathize with Starr and her actions.
Furthermore the reader understands her problems and the process to solve the problems.
It gets clear that itsit's hard for Starr to speak up for Khalil, but the reader also understands her anger and why she speaks up for Khalil at the end of the excerpt.

In Conclusionconclusion you can say that she is happy with the change of the state of her mind and the process to overcome her fear, which is emphasized through various narrative techniques like her inner monologmonologue.
